Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 10:35PM Jodian72 wrote: Also was a piece of cake for me! I expected a horrible 'surgery' experience. It was pretty basic. I was literally wheeled straight over for my first chemo treatment immediatly following putting it in... and they used it that time. It was a little sore for a couple weeks. I have to be careful when I shower not to rake the bar of soap over it.... that really hurts. LOL. But other than that, it's pretty simple. I just had those steri-strips on mine and didn't even have any internal stitches from it. The steri-strips fell off after about 3 or 4 days. Good luck... Jodi
Posts.Title: Port Question AO44 Areyousure

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2008 09:28PM Jodian72 wrote: Oh, that is wonderful!!! Congrats... Jodi
Posts.Title: Scan Results In kenzie57 LoriFL

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2007 04:36PM Jodian72 wrote: I had a swollen lymph node above my right clavical for about four weeks. It was prior to my 'true' diagnosis so was looked into pretty closely after my dx. All of my scans came back showing nothing in the node. It was so painful and it kept me up at night. Now it is completely gone. For me, It was just one of those mysteries of the body. I hope this is all it is for you. I was so scared reading stuff in the web about it. It all pointed to really serious stuff. Mine turned out to be nothing, which is amazing considering the dx I have! Good luck and I hope this finds you well. Keep us posted. Jodi

Posts.Title: FDA Alert re: Fentanyl Patch saluki LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2008 03:57AM Jodian72 wrote: Yup... two weeks after starting A/C I lost it all! First treatment was 11/13 and I had nothing on my head by 12/3! Have my eyebrows and lashes... but they are thin. Lost most of my pubic hair first, that went within a week. Hair on my legs is pretty thin, but it was always thin and blonde anyway. It never really bothered me much. I forget I don't have hair and in my dreams I usually have really long hair. It's starting to come back in a tiny, tiny bit. I have baby fuzz along my neck and up on my forehead hairline. I also have a few crazies here and there popping out. It's just part of the adventure for me. Cheers, Jodi
Posts.Title: Did you lose all of your hair on chemo? liven42day Jodian72

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 06:54PM Jodian72 wrote: When it was really, really bad I used a fentanyl patch. Started at 25mcg and went up to 50 mcg. I was told to change them every three days. It really helped. I mean REALLY! After some chemo I had a lot of pain relief, so now I use ibuprofen. If I feel especially icky after chemo I'll go to the bottle of Norco or Darvocet... but usually the ibuprofen does the trick. Thank Goodness! Good luck, I hope you have some relief soon. Cheers, Jodi
Posts.Title: what type of pain mets are used for bone mets? prayer mason204

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2008 07:13AM Jodian72 wrote: Hi Joni... My onc just added Gemzar to my Taxotere treatments. I can't take Taxol as I'm really allergic to it. So far I'm feeling pretty good. Just had chemo yesterday. Some insane indigestion and I feel hot all over... no fever though. :) My onc has put me back on the Nuelasta shot because she said the Gemzar can make counts lower. I do two weeks on, one week off of the Taxotere plus Gemzar. I also get Zometa once a month for the bone mets. Glad to hear you are doing ok. Good luck, Jodi
Posts.Title: Start new chemo Taxol/Gemzar tomorrow jonimb Jodian72

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 01:29PM Jodian72 wrote: Thanks... I really needed to see that. It's been rough lately. I want to kick a$$, too! :) Jodi
Posts.Title: Talked to someone 22 yrs w/ bone mets!! gracem Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2008 02:48PM Jodian72 wrote: I'm weird about the pink ribbon thing, too. I wonder if there is a ribbon for mets? My bc is really second to my mets... and most people don't even know or understand what mets is. I have this one pin that my Mom got me and I used to wear it all the time. When I lost my hair I stopped wearing it. I'm not completely sure why... maybe I didn't want the label to match the product? My dh brings me things all the time. It's really sweet and I think its part of his coping mechanism. I will admit that I bought pink ribbon slippers and a T-shirt. I wear the slippers all around the house, but have had a hard time wearing the t-shirt out. Again... don't want the label to match the product??? I guess for me, I don't care for the 'pity' looks. I don't know... That's my two cents... Jodi
Posts.Title: I hate pink ribbons, but.......... Watson Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2008 12:27AM Jodian72 wrote: Well, I feel pretty good. I'm tired today, but I just had a baby last friday. I've had three rounds of chemo starting on Nov. 13th. The first one was the hardest, but I had the port put in that morning and went straight to chemo. I also had a TON of pain from my mets, which slowly subsided within a couple weeks of first chemo. I appreciate my chemo because it has made me feel better. I usually notice I'm really tired at about day 5 and it lasts for 4 or 5 days. I very rarely get 'sick' or diarhea (sp?) and mostly just eat really bland food. This next round (next week) will be my first NOT being pregnant, so I don't know how different it will be. Good luck... Jodi

Posts.Title: What did you get for Christmas? luckywife dash

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2008 05:37PM Jodian72 wrote: I have bone mets on my hip and both femurs (not to mention many other locations) and I was diagnosed with bc stage 4 after being on dissability from sciatica for a month. I couldn't even walk. I hope that is not what you are dealing with, but it's good you have an appointment. Mine is currently under control and I have very little pain in my lower back and legs. Good luck.
Posts.Title: bone mets?? MaryK9 LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2007 01:29AM Jodian72 wrote: I have bone mets dx in Oct 07'. I don't feel so bad now. I have had 3 rounds of chemo and after the first round (Nov. 13th) my pain was so much better. I am also using fentanyl patches (currently 25 micrograms). I'm not sure I even need them any more, but I have been told that I have to ween off of them. I was using Fentanyl 50's along with 2 Norco's (like Vicoden) every four hours back in the 'beginning'. But as you can see, I've only been undergoing treatment for a little over 6 weeks. Moving forward, I guess my biggest concerns are the weakening of the bones. I have bone mets to the spine, shoulder, both hips, and my femurs. So, pretty extensive stuff. I'm thankful that I don't feel worse! Good luck to you. I hope you find some relief and answers from your onc soon. Waiting for answers is so difficult sometimes. I hope my words are comforting in some way. Cheers, Jodi
Posts.Title: new to Club Mets Topaz1110 Watson

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2008 10:55PM Jodian72 wrote: I second the fentanyl patches suggestion. There are many different levels of patches as well. Jodi
Posts.Title: hospice and pain control cats_love_me mimi1030

Posts.Content: Jodian72 wrote: Wow, that sounds weird. Kind of like that song, 'Bad to the Bone'. I'm posting here now, as it seems the appropriate place. Today I received my 'official' diagnosis of breast cancer metastatic to the bone. I have spots on my spine, neck, hips, and ribs. Fortunately, no organ involvement. I was originally scheduled for mastectomy tomorrow, but of course that has now changed. I will start chemo a.s.a.p. Maybe as soon as this Thursday. I'm 6 mo. pregnant today, so it complicates the treatment a bit. At this point we will treat the cancer with chemo to 'hold it off' until the baby comes. Then we will treat more aggressively. I see a perinatologist on Wednesday as I'm a high risk pregnancy now. I'm 34 (35 the end of this month) and this is my first pregnancy. I'm feeling very positive about this whole thing. I'm not too worried as my onc seems very confident in my treatment. It's just scary with baby and all. I want my baby to be healthy when she is born. So that is all I can think of to share about me right now. Just thought I would step up and join you all. Cheers, Jodi My Zoe's website: www.babysites.com/sites/zoeann Dx 10/27/2007, ILC, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Hello, I'm metastatic to the bone Jodian72 Traci-----TripNeg

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2007 02:16AM Jodian72 wrote: I also wear the fentanyl patch. I'll be reducing the dosage this week to 25 micrograms instead of 50 micrograms. I'm not supposed to really drive while using this med, so it's probably not a good option for you. I haven't experienced 'flare-ups', but then I was only diagnosed 2 months ago and have been on chemo and pain meds since then. I'm looking forward to reading other experiences as I have been wondering about this moving forward. I had read that it can do that, 'flare-up' I mean... what a pain! No pun intended.   Take care and I hope you find some good relief soon. Cheers, Jodi
Posts.Title: Advice on day to day strategies living with bone mets mason204 Shepgirl

Posts.Content: Jodian72 wrote: So I went to start chemo up again the other day. I started with the standard fluids, then Zomeda, then anti-nausea, then (I think) tagamet and on to the Taxol. About 5 minutes in to the taxol I felt like I had an elephant on my chest and realized I couldn't really breath. I had Zoe in my arms and passed her off to my hubby. I called the nurse and she came over and said, "It's an allergic reaction." The whole staff 'sprung' into action. They were amazing! They started pumping me full of benadryl and then... the pain started. OMG... I thought my back was going to explode. It came in waves and hurt so bad I was white knuckling the chair. My DH freaked out (he always does) but the nurses calmed him down. They gave me a lot of morphine and it took nearly an hour for the pain to really subside. Needless to say, I don't remember much for the rest of the day... whoohoo, good drugs. LOL. So they said that this does happen, but I had and extremely severe reaction. How scary! Has this happened to anyone else and what did they change you to? I think we are looking into Taxotere now. Just another Jodi saga... I swear, I'm like a cockroach, you just can't kill me!!!!! Cheers... Jodi My Zoe's website: www.babysites.com/sites/zoeann Dx 10/27/2007, ILC, Stage IV, Grade 2, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

I also have a prescription for decodran (sp?) now. WendyV... thanks for the nice comment about being a tree, kind of brought tears to my eyes... :) Smiles, Jodi
